name: Sicilian Defense
description: Most played defense vs 1.e4 at all levels
strategy: The Sicilian Defense is Black's most popular response to 1.e4, offering dynamic counterplay and avoiding symmetrical positions. Black aims for unbalanced positions with chances for active piece play.

reactions.note: Sveshnikov or Classical - aggressive and sharp
Kan or Taimanov - more flexible structure

name: Ruy Lopez (Spanish Opening)
description: Most classical 1.e4 e5 opening; used in world championships
strategy: The Ruy Lopez is one of the oldest and most classical chess openings. White develops quickly while putting pressure on Black's e5 pawn and the knight defending it.

name: Italian Game (Giuoco Piano)
description: Popular at all levels; safe and flexible
strategy: The Italian Game focuses on rapid development and control of the center. White develops the bishop to an aggressive square, targeting the f7 pawn.

name: Slav Defense
description: Ultra-solid response to 1.d4; common in elite play
strategy: The Slav Defense supports the d5 pawn with the c-pawn, maintaining central stability while keeping the light-squared bishop free to develop.

name: Nimzo-Indian Defense
pgn: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4
strategy: Black pins the knight and threatens to double White's pawns. This hypermodern defense focuses on controlling key central squares rather than occupying them.

reactions.note: Classical Variation. White defends the c3 knight and prepares for the center. Black castles and prepares to fianchetto the queen's bishop.
Rubinstein Variation. White develops the kingside. Black prepares to control the center from the queenside.
Sämisch Variation. White forces a pawn exchange. Black accepts the doubled pawns for better development and control of the e4 square.
Three Knights Variation. A flexible developing move by White, often transposing to other lines. Black develops and challenges White's plans.
Kmoch Variation. White tries to prepare e4. Black immediately strikes at the center to prevent this.

name: King's Indian Defense
pgn: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. Nc3 Bg7
description: Aggressive weapon vs 1.d4; championed by Fischer
strategy: Black allows White to build a strong pawn center while preparing a kingside fianchetto. This leads to sharp, tactical games with attacking chances for both sides.

reactions.opponentMove: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. Nc3 Bg7
1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. Nf3 Bg7
1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. Nc3 d5
reactions.note: Transposes to Grunfeld - expect open center

name: Grunfeld Defense
pgn: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. Nc3 d5
strategy: Black immediately challenges White's center with d5, creating dynamic imbalances and tactical complications. Highly theoretical with sharp variations.

reactions.note: Main line — sharp and highly theoretical
Russian System — avoids early central push
Quiet system — White builds tension gradually

name: Caro-Kann Defense
description: Very popular vs 1.e4; solid and counterpunching
strategy: Black prepares d5 while maintaining a solid pawn structure. This defense aims for a solid position with good piece coordination and counterplay opportunities.

reactions.note: Advance Variation: squeeze space, play slow buildup

name: French Defense
description: Rich pawn structures; polarizing but common
strategy: Black prepares d5 and accepts a somewhat cramped but solid position. This leads to complex pawn structures and strategic maneuvering.

reactions.note: Advance Variation — strong space for White

name: English Opening
description: Flexible and used at top level (Carlsen, Kramnik)
strategy: White controls d5 and e4 from the flank, maintaining flexibility in piece development. This opening can transpose to many different pawn structures.

reactions.note: Reversed Sicilian — sharp but familiar ideas

name: Scotch Game
description: Direct and tactical 1.e4 e5 opening; resurging in online blitz
strategy: White immediately opens the center with d4, leading to tactical complications. Popular in blitz games due to its direct, forcing nature.

name: London System
description: Very popular at amateur level for its simplicity
strategy: White develops the bishop to f4 early, creating a solid setup that's easy to learn and play. Popular among club players for its straightforward development.

reactions.note: Standard London setup against classical structure
Develop bishop early before committing center

name: Catalan Opening
description: Top-level favorite due to strategic richness
strategy: White combines the Queen's Gambit with a kingside fianchetto, creating pressure on the long diagonal while maintaining central control.

reactions.note: Closed Catalan — quiet buildup with central pressure
Check variation — delays typical fianchetto lines

name: Petrov's Defense (Russian Game)
description: Used for equality-seeking at elite level
strategy: Black immediately counterattacks White's e4 pawn, leading to symmetrical positions. Often used when Black wants to minimize risk and play for equality.

reactions.note: White aims for fast development with central pressure
Four Knights with Petrov — hybrid structure

name: Alekhine's Defense
description: Sharp and aggressive; common in faster time controls
strategy: Black immediately attacks the e4 pawn, provoking White to advance and potentially overextend. Popular in blitz for its unbalancing potential.

reactions.note: Chases knight early — sharper and riskier

name: Benoni Defense
strategy: Black creates an asymmetrical pawn structure, fighting for piece activity and counterplay rather than central control. Leads to sharp, tactical games.

reactions.note: Old Benoni structure — quick center tension

name: Modern Defense
strategy: Black fianchettoes the king's bishop and allows White to build a pawn center, planning to undermine it later. Flexible and hypermodern approach.

name: Trompowsky Attack
description: A practical weapon at all levels
strategy: White develops the bishop aggressively, putting immediate pressure on Black's kingside. A practical choice that avoids main theoretical lines.

name: Scandinavian Defense
strategy: Black immediately challenges White's central pawn, forcing an early queen development. Simple to learn but can lead to early queen activity for White.

reactions.note: Modern variation — avoids early queen exposure
Less common sideline — aiming for rapid development
